climbs.name: Spacely Sprockets
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, John Thackray, and Peggy Buckey, March 1987

content.description: This is a good quality face climb, with four bolts.
content.location: This is a slab route at the right end of the northwest face.

content.description:
Start just right of

Montague Jetson

(the water groove/chimney) at a shallow groove that leads up the face. Make difficult moves to enter the groove, then up easier face climbing to the obvious horizontal crack and a ledge to the left (toward the gully).

Red, gold, blue and purple Camalots for anchor and directional.
content.protection: Red, gold, blue and purple Camalots for anchor and directional.
content.location:
Start just right of

Montague Jetson

(the water groove/chimney) at a shallow groove that leads up the face.

content.description:
Start about 25 feet up and right of

Spacely Sprockets

and

Cogswell's Cosmic Cogs

at a pine tree. Climb the face above the pine, passing the juncture of two cracks. Continue up the flaky face above to the top.

Gold, blue and grey Camalots (or equivalent) needed for an anchor.
content.protection: Gold, blue and grey Camalots (or equivalent) needed for an anchor.
content.location:
Start about 25 feet up and right of

Spacely Sprockets

and

Cogswell's Cosmic Cogs

at a pine tree.

content.description:
Before rappel anchors were installed atop the Pea Brain, this was the historic descent route for the formation (most people rappelled the lower portion from slings around a jammed boulder). The line makes an OK ascent route for geriatrics.

Start at the height of land in the rocky canyon between Pea Brain and Fat Freddy's Cat. There's a boulder leaning against the base of the Pea Brain face, directly under a water runnel that leads to a gully. This is the start of the route.

Climb the short water runnel (crux) to a couple jammed boulders and a small oak. Climb the gully above, using a hand crack in the back of the gully and stemming to reach the top.

Move left and rappel from an anchor  down

Elroy Was Here

with a single 60m rope (30m rappel).
content.protection: Carry some hand-sized pieces of gear and a few shoulder-length slings.
content.location: Start at the height of land in the rocky canyon between Pea Brain and Fat Freddy's Cat. There's a boulder leaning against the base of the Pea Brain face, directly under a water runnel that leads to a gully. This is the start of the route.

climbs.name: Joan Jetson
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Kelly Carignan, Marge Floyd and Charles Cole, 1985

content.protection: Gear for belay or a bit off the left is a rap station that may be subsituted.

content.description:
Begin about 20 feet right of

Montague Jetson

below an obvious crack. Climb the crack to its end, then angle up and left to a ledge.

Red, gold, blue and purple Camalots for the anchor and directional.
content.protection: Red, gold, blue and purple Camalots for the anchor and directional.
content.location:
Begin about 20 feet right of

Montague Jetson

below an obvious crack.

content.description:
Climb the face left of a gully (

Montague Jetson

) to the anchor on

Cogswell's Cosmic Cogs

. The upper section of this route climbs V1 as described in

Cogswell's Cosmic Cogs

.
content.protection: You can rappel down the route in one rappel with a single 60m rope (30m rappel).
content.location:
Start about 70 feet up and right of the start of

Cogswell's Cosmic Cogs

and 10 feet left of a gully (

Montague Jetson

).

climbs.name: Dihedron
climbs.fa: (Aid) Randy Leavitt or Bob Gaines & Curt Stitz, 1989; FFA: Randy Leavitt, January 1997

content.description: There is only one established (2017) 5.14 trad route in all of Joshua Tree per Miramontes extensive (3000+ routes) guide and it is located on Pea Brain: Dihedron (5.14a**), established by Randy Leavitt in 1997.

Start just right of

Spacely Sprockets

at an obvious right arching crack.

Pitch 1: Climb up an easy slab to reach the right arching crack. Follow the crack up and right to a belay near an arête (5.9+).

Pitch 2: Follow the crack right around the corner then up and right to the top of the formation (5.7+; V1).

Variation 1: Instead of doing the 2nd pitch, climb the face above the P1 belay to the top (5.6+).
content.protection: Carry a standard JT rack with some extra finger to thin hands cams.
content.location:
Start just right of

Spacely Sprockets

at an obvious right-arching crack.

Descend by rappelling down

Elroy Was Here

with a single 60m rope (30m rappel).

climbs.name: Cactus Dog
climbs.fa: Troy Mayr, Steve Anderson, Beth Anderson and Kelly Penix, 1990

content.description:
Boulder high onto the base of the Pea Brain for the start of the route.

The first bolt isn't immediately visible, so don't panic as you eyeball the second.

Work your way up easy shelves to the first bolt.  Continue through bolts 2 and 3 on the somewhat crispy face.  The crux is getting to 4, with cool moves past it up and onto the dike.  Two more spaced bolts can be found as you move through easier terrain.
content.protection: 6 bolts (5/16" Button Heads).  3 Bolt Anchor, setup for rappel.  With a 60m rope you need to downclimb 4th class for a bit.
content.location: The route is located on the southwest shoulder of the Pea Brain.

content.description:
This route climbs the face on the right-hand side of the gully of

Montague Jetson

. Start just right of the oak that is midway up the gully, atop a boulder.

Climb straight up the featured face above the boulder to a terrace (V1).

Variation 1: By moving out right from the boulder and then up, the route is about 5.6.
content.protection: With blue & gold Camalots, an anchor rope and a couple small TCUs, you can rig a TR anchor for this route.
content.location:
This route climbs the face on the right-hand side of the gully of

Montague Jetson

. Start just right of the oak that is midway up the gully, atop a boulder.
